places.name: Phlegraean Fields
places.description: A large region of supervolcanic calderas situated to the west of Naples, Italy.

places.name: Naples
places.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

places.name: Naples
places.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: Gottfried WilhelmLeibniz
persons.description: A German polymath active as a mathematician, philosopher, scientist and diplomat who invented calculus

persons.name: Georg ErnstStahl
persons.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

persons.name: HermanBoerhaave
persons.description: Dutch botanist, chemist, Christian humanist, and physician.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: BenjaminThompson
persons.description: Born in Massachusetts, he served in the British and Bavarian armies. Knighted by George III in 1787, the Elector of Bavaria created him Reichsgraf von Rumford of the Holy Roman Empire in 1792. His appointment in the late 1790s as Bavarian ambassador to London created a minor diplomatic incident, during which he helped establish and manage the Royal Institution, in the course of which he appointed Davy to lecture there. Later he married Lavoisier's widow and lived unhappily ever after. FRSL.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: BenjaminThompson
persons.description: Born in Massachusetts, he served in the British and Bavarian armies. Knighted by George III in 1787, the Elector of Bavaria created him Reichsgraf von Rumford of the Holy Roman Empire in 1792. His appointment in the late 1790s as Bavarian ambassador to London created a minor diplomatic incident, during which he helped establish and manage the Royal Institution, in the course of which he appointed Davy to lecture there. Later he married Lavoisier's widow and lived unhappily ever after. FRSL.

persons.name: Rene-AntoineRéaumur
persons.description: French entomologist who developed a widely used temperature scale. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Alexis ThérèsePetit
persons.description: French physicist known for his work on air and steam engines. The Dulong-Petit law of thermodynamics is named after him and his collaborator Pierre-Louis Dulong.

persons.name: Pierre LouisDulong
persons.description: French physicist and chemist who worked mostly on specific heats, but also discovered nitrogen chloride around the same time as Davy. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Alexander John GaspardMarcet
persons.description: Genevean-born physician who settled in London and lectured on chemistry at Guy's Hospital. A friend of Davy's. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnFreeborn
persons.description: Banker, merchant and British cousul in Rome.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

persons.name: Saint Paul
persons.description: A Christian apostle who spread the teachings of Jesus in the first-century world. For his contributions towards the New Testament, he is generally regarded as one of the most important figures of the Apostolic Age.

persons.name: JesusChrist
persons.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: Philalethes
persons.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

places.name: River Danube
places.description: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. It flows through central and south eastern Europe into the Black Sea.

places.name: Drava River
places.description: The Drava is a river in central southern Europe and is the fifth longest tributary of the Danube.

places.name: Styria
places.description: Styria is a state in the south-east of Austria.

places.name: Rhine
places.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

places.name: Sava River
places.description: The Sava River, 990km in length, rises in Slovenia (Carnolia) and is the largest tributary of the Danube by volume of water.

places.name: Julian Alps
places.description: The Julian Alps are a mountain range in the Southern Limestone Alps, Slovenia. Mount Triglav is the highest point.

places.name: Illyrian Alps
places.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

places.name: Illyrian Alps
places.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

places.name: Ljubljana
places.description: Also known as Laybach or Laibach. Ljubljana is the capital city of Slovenia.

persons.name: JohnHunter
persons.description: Leading Scottish surgeon and anatomist who worked in London, holding several major positions. Brother of William Hunter. FRSL.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: GeorgeDuring
persons.description: His Majesty's Consul in Triest in 1829 who helped Davy obtain recently caught Torpedos for his experiments.

places.name: Trieste
places.description: Trieste is the capital city of the Friuli Venezia Giulia region in north-east Italy. A port city, it occupies a thin strip of land between the Adriatic coast and Slovenia’s border on the limestone-dominated Karst Plateau.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
works.author: Humphry Davy

persons.name: AlessandroVolta
persons.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Hans ChristianØrsted
persons.description: Danish physicist and chemist who won the Copley Medal in 1820 for his electro-chemical experiments and discoveries; he had become a professor at the University of Copenhagen in 1806.

places.name: Milan
places.description: A city in northern Italy, and the capital of Lombardy.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

places.name: Mola di Gaeta
places.description: Italian village on the coast between Rome and Naples.

places.name: Rimini
places.description: A city in north-eastern Italy located on the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

persons.name: AlessandroVolta
persons.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Bay of Naples
places.description: The Bay (or Gulf) of Naples is located on the south-western coast of Italy, with Naples to the north, Vesuvius to the east, and the Sorrento Peninsula to the south.

places.name: Mediterranean Sea
places.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

persons.name: JohnWalsh
persons.description: Nabob and later an MP he experimented on the electrical properties of torpedo fish. FRSL.

places.description: Three lakes (Lough Leane, Muckross Lake - also called Middle Lake, and Upper Lake) surrounded by the MacGillycuddy's Reeks and now part of Killarney National Park.

places.description: County in the peninsular southwest of Ireland.

places.name: Northern Ireland

places.name: Keeper Hill

places.name: Mucrish
places.description: Muckish, one of the Derryveagh Mountains. See the poem 'Mucrish and Arokil, ye pair...' in Tait's Edinburgh Magazine for 1836, vol. iii, p. 252. See also Memoirs, vol. 1, pp. 287 ff.

places.name: Limerick
places.description: Limerick is a city in Ireland, set in Munster province in the south of the country.

places.name: Wurzen Pass
places.description: Wurzen Pass is a mountain pass in a col of the Karawanks Mountain range between the Austrian state of Carinthia and the the Slovenian Kranjska Gora. It is named after the town of Podkoren (Wurzen).

persons.name: Franz JosefGall
persons.description: German-born, he later worked in Paris on phrenology.

places.name: Piazza Poli
places.description: Davy refers to No.78 Piazza di Poli near the Trevi Fountain in Rome, presumably as somewhere he stayed.

persons.name: Ambrosio
persons.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

persons.name: Stephan LudwigJacobi
persons.description: German landowner and inventor who developed the first trout hatchery in Germany.

persons.name: JaneDavy
persons.description: Daughter of Charles Kerr, an Antiguan merchant who made his fortune in highly dubious circumstances. Following his death she moved to Britain where she married Schukbrugh Apreece who died in 1807. After running a successful literary salon in Edinburgh she moved to London where she met Davy and they married on 11 April 1812 two days after he had been knighted by the Prince Regent.

works.name: Salmonia: or Days of Fly Fishing. In a Series of Conversations.
works.author: Humphry Davy

persons.name: JohnMurray
persons.description: Publisher of many of the key literary and scientific texts of the time, including by Byron, Austen, Davy. Published The Quarterly Journal of Science (closely likned to the Royal Institution) as well as Davy's Six Discourses (1827), Salmonia (1828) and Consolations in Travel (1830).

persons.name: EdwardJenner
persons.description: Lived in Berkeley, Gloucestershire, where he pioneered vacination, especially for smallpox. FRSL.

places.name: Palazzo Fiano
places.description: Historic building in Rome, with a painted ceiling featuring many mythological figures and a hall of mirrors.

places.name: The Colosseum
places.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

persons.name: Hipparchus
persons.description: a Greek astronomer, geographer, and mathematician. He is considered the founder of trigonometry, but is most famous for his incidental discovery of the precession of the equinoxes.

persons.name: John Frederick WilliamHerschel
persons.description: Son of William Herschel and a ploymathic mathematician, natural philosopher, astronomer and chemist who coined the word photograph. Unsuccesful in being elected President of the Royal Society of London, he later became Master of the Mint. FRSL.

places.name: The Colosseum
places.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

persons.name: PeterRomanov
persons.description: Peter I of Russia, also known as Peter the Great.  The first emperor of all Russia who was responsible for huge cultural changes, replacing some of the traditionalist and medieval social and political systems with ones that were modern, scientific, Westernized, and based on radical Enlightenment.

persons.name: GalileoGalilei
persons.description: Italian astronomer, physicist, and engineer.

persons.name: Socrates
persons.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: Moses
persons.description: According to the Old Testament Hebrew prophet who is considered the most important prophet in Judaism and one of the most important prophets in Christianity and other religions.

persons.name: Attila
persons.description: The ruler of the Huns from 434 until his death.

persons.name: Alaric
persons.description: Leader of the Visigoths who led the sack of Rome in 410 CE.

places.name: United States
places.description: The U.S. is a country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation’s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

persons.name: Archimedes
persons.description: Ancient Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, astronomer and inventor from Syracuse in Sicily.

persons.name: GalileoGalilei
persons.description: Italian astronomer, physicist, and engineer.

persons.name: Socrates
persons.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

persons.name: Anaxagoras
persons.description: Greek Presocratic philosopher.

persons.name: RogerBacon
persons.description: Medieval English philosopher and Franciscan friar.

persons.name: Alfred
persons.description: King of the West Saxons from 871 to 886, and King of the Anglo-Saxons from 886 until his death in 899.

places.name: United States

persons.name: Tamerlane
persons.description: a Turco-Mongol conqueror who founded the Timurid Empire in and around modern-day Afghanistan, Iran, and Central Asia, becoming the first ruler of the Timurid dynasty.

persons.name: Muhammad
persons.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

persons.name: GengisKhan
persons.description: The founder and first khan of the Mongol Empire.

places.name: Black Sea
places.description: The Black Sea is a marginal Mediterranean sea lying between Europe and Asia, east of the Balkans, south of the East European Plain, west of the Caucasus, and north of Anatolia.

places.name: River Thames
places.description: The River Thames, known alternatively in parts as the River Isis, is a river that flows through southern England including London.

places.name: Baltic Sea
places.description: The Baltic Sea is an arm of the Atlantic Ocean that is enclosed by Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Russia, Sweden, and the North and Central European Plain.

places.name: Rhine
places.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

places.name: Delaware River
places.description: a major river in the Mid-Atlantic region of the United States and is the longest free-flowing river in the Eastern United States.

places.name: St. Lawrence River
places.description: a large international river in the middle latitudes of North America connecting the Great Lakes to the North Atlantic Ocean.

places.name: France
places.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.

persons.description: German (or in some accounts Danish or Greek) alchemist, credited with the invention of gunpowder.

places.name: Rome

places.name: Athens

places.name: Arabian Peninsula
places.description: a peninsula in West Asia, situated northeast of Africa on the Arabian Plate. It includes the territories of includes Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Yemen, as well as southern Iraq and Jordan. In the classical era, the Sinai Peninsula was also considered a part of Arabia.

places.name: Apennines
places.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

places.name: Africa
places.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

places.name: Ganges
places.description: The Ganges is a river in Asia running through India and Bangladesh. It is part of the third largest river on earth.

places.name: Niger
places.description: The main river of West Africa, extending about 4,180 km.

places.name: Niniveh

places.name: Carthage
places.description: an ancient city on the eastern side of the Lake of Tunis in what is now Tunisia. Carthage was one of the most important trading hubs of the Ancient Mediterranean and one of the most affluent cities of the classical world.

places.name: Troy
places.description: an ancient city located in present-day Hisarlik, Turkey. It is best known as the setting for the Trojan War.

places.name: Memphis

places.name: Babylon

places.name: Thebes, Egypt

places.name: Tyre

persons.name: St. Peter
